text: The abstract reads as follows.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Research linking genetic differences with human social and behavioral phenotypes has long been controversial.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Frequently, debates about the ethical, social, and legal implications of this area of research center on questions about whether studies overtly or covertly perpetuate genetic determinism, genetic essentialism, and or genetic reductionism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Given the prominent role of the isms in scientific discourse and criticism, it is important for there to be consensus and clarity about the meaning of these terms.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Here, the author integrates scholarship from psychology, genetics, and philosophy of science to provide accessible definitions of genetic determinism, genetic reductionism, and genetic essentialism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The author provides linguistic and visual examples of determinism, reductionism, and essentialism in science and popular culture, discusses common misconceptions, and concludes with recommendations for science communication.

text: What is determinism?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Determinism is a philosophical term about the causal structure of the universe and has been defined as follows.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The world is governed by determinism if and only if, given a specified way things are at time t, the way things go thereafter is fixed as a matter of natural law.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Carrying this forward, genetic determinism can therefore be defined as follows.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A phenotype is governed by genetic determinism if and only if, given a specified genotype, the way the phenotype develops thereafter is fixed as a matter of natural law.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A genetically determined phenotype, according to this definition, is a necessary occurrence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If one knows the genotype, then one can foretell the phenotype with a very high degree of certainty, regardless of social or environmental context.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is obviously an extreme case of high heritability across multiple examined contexts.

text: Onto the second of the three categories, essentialism.

text: So, genetic essentialism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Essentialism is the belief that things have essences, one or more deep underlying characteristics without which the thing or person would not be what it is, and that these essences explain why certain individual things or people are appropriately considered members of the same category.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That is, essentialism is a theory that structures how concepts and categories are organized, including social categories such as gender or race.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thus, while determinism is a belief about why something comes to be, essentialism is a belief about what makes things similar to or unlike another thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, one holding a determinist belief will overlook environmental influences such as sun exposure and believe that skin tone is genetically determined.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One holding an essentialist belief will believe that people who have a similarly dark skin tone share an underlying essence, such that their superficial similarity reflects a deeper property that explains what they are all, quote, really like.

text: There are also important differences between determinist and essentialist beliefs with regard to how genetic information is used in moral judgments.

text: Deterministic thinking conceptualizes the genome as a constraint on one's ability to be or to have done otherwise, which might lead to diminished judgments of blameworthiness.

text: Thus, genetic information might reduce judgments of blameworthiness or praiseworthiness if that information is understood through the lens of determinism, but increase those judgments if genetic information is understood through the lens of essentialism.
